title: The Writing on the Wall
shortSummary: Daniel Chapter 5 recounts the dramatic story of King Belshazzar's feast, during which a mysterious hand writes a divine message on the palace wall. Daniel interprets the writing, pronouncing judgment on Belshazzar's pride and sacrilege, leading to the fall of Babylon and the rise of the Medes and Persians.
timeline: c. 539 BC - Fall of Babylon under Belshazzar's reign

keyCharacters.name: Belshazzar
keyCharacters.description: The king of Babylon who holds a blasphemous feast and faces divine judgment for his arrogance and disrespect toward God.

keyCharacters.name: Daniel
keyCharacters.description: A Jewish exile and wise man gifted by God with the ability to interpret dreams and mysterious writings; he interprets the writing on the wall.

keyCharacters.name: Nebuchadnezzar
keyCharacters.description: Belshazzar’s father and former king of Babylon, whose pride and subsequent humbling serve as a warning example in Daniel’s message.

keyCharacters.name: The Queen
keyCharacters.description: A wise woman who advises Belshazzar to call Daniel to interpret the mysterious writing.

definitions.definition: Practitioners who claimed to interpret the stars and celestial events to predict the future, often associated with pagan practices.
Individuals who professed to foretell events or reveal hidden knowledge through supernatural means, condemned in Scripture.
Aramaic words written on the wall meaning 'numbered, numbered, weighed, divided,' symbolizing God's judgment on Babylon.
A rich red cloth symbolizing honor and high status, given to Daniel as a reward.

outline.heading: Belshazzar’s Blasphemous Feast
outline.description: Belshazzar hosts a great feast using sacred vessels from the Jerusalem temple to drink wine and praise false gods, demonstrating his irreverence toward the true God.

outline.heading: The Mysterious Writing Appears
outline.description: A supernatural hand writes a cryptic message on the palace wall, causing terror among the king and his wise men who fail to interpret it.

outline.heading: Daniel Called to Interpret
outline.description: The queen suggests calling Daniel, who is renowned for his God-given wisdom; Daniel is summoned and offered rewards for interpreting the writing.

outline.heading: Daniel’s Interpretation and Judgment
outline.description: Daniel recounts Nebuchadnezzar’s pride and fall, then pronounces God’s judgment on Belshazzar for his arrogance and sacrilege, interpreting the writing as the end of his kingdom.

outline.heading: The Fall of Babylon and Daniel’s Promotion
outline.description: Belshazzar is slain that very night, Babylon falls to Darius the Median, and Daniel is honored as the third ruler in the kingdom.

application: Recognize the seriousness of pride and irreverence toward God, avoiding any form of blasphemy or disrespect in our lives.
Trust in God’s sovereignty over kingdoms and circumstances, knowing He appoints and removes rulers according to His will.
Seek God’s wisdom and understanding through prayer and Scripture, as Daniel did, rather than relying on worldly knowledge or occult practices.
Respond humbly to God’s warnings and discipline to avoid the consequences of rebellion and disobedience.

keyVerses.text: But hast lifted up thyself against the Lord of heaven; and they have brought the vessels of his house before thee, and thou, and thy lords, thy wives, and thy concubines, have drunk wine in them; and thou hast praised the gods of silver, and gold, of brass, iron, wood, and stone, which see not, nor hear, nor know: and the God in whose hand thy breath is, and whose are all thy ways, hast thou not glorified:
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights Belshazzar’s blatant disrespect toward God, a key reason for his downfall.

keyVerses.text: This is the interpretation of the thing: MENE; God hath numbered thy kingdom, and finished it. TEKEL; Thou art weighed in the balances, and art found wanting. PERES; Thy kingdom is divided, and given to the Medes and Persians.
keyVerses.significance: These verses contain the divine judgment against Babylon, revealing God’s sovereign control over history.

keyVerses.text: In that night was Belshazzar the king of the Chaldeans slain.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows the immediate fulfillment of God’s judgment following Daniel’s interpretation.
